ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The presentations people did before the field trip were very useful to orient ourselves to the South. I would recommend splitting the event into two nights and having everyone present before the field trip. It did not work out having people present during the trip.
This is one of the most valuable parts of the forestry curriculum, by far the most "real-world" which is a current weakness in the program.

The opportunity for field observation and on the ground experience is CRUCIAL to a forestry education. This class is a hallmark of the school's program and should be continued at all costs. It adds a tremendous amount of learning to the forestry curriculum. Plus, it offers insight into industrial operations that are impossible to find close to campus. Moreover, our alums in the South love hosting us and showing us the forests and company's they care for. It is a wonderful class all around. Highlight of my time at FES!

I answer this question instead of the initial set because the field trip was a unique class experience. It was by far one of my most memorable experiences at F&ES - both academically and socially. The instructors were incredible as were the speakers and other students. I learned more from this trip in a week than I could have ever imagined. In addition, the trip was a great way to practice the knowledge I had already gained from other forestry courses.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The best aspects of this course were meeting with the people at different organizations. It was fascinating hearing their very different opinions on how forests should be managed. I loved hearing from people ranging from plantation foresters to bird biologists.

The people that we meet with. They give students a great perspective on forestry from a diversity of viewpoints. Also, if the professors are able to keep their mouths shut, the visitors are able to teach very well.
Having the opportunity to spend a week outside with our very knowledgeable professors and hosts was invaluable.
Ann and Mike are incomparably attentive and friendly to students and are just a great team to see in action. Our hosts were well-chosen and gracious.

The value of seeing forestry in practice, on the ground, is unparalleled. To physically interact with a forest managed by field foresters practicing the Stoddard-Neel approach is dramatically better than reading alone. Meeting the various folks on the field trip who work in forestry is amazing and only surpassed by gaining a deeper understanding of classmates.

Getting to spend time in the field with our excellent teachers (Dr. Camp & Mike Ferrucci), with practitioners and researchers. I never would have otherwise gotten to know forestry in the south. Great trip.
The burn was great and good to see how real forestry is done.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Though this course was excellent and I loved every stop we made I would recommend only making the trip 7 days instead of 8. Also, a little bit more free time each day would have been nice.
The professors, Ann and Mike, need to chill out a bit. For the first part of the trip they came off as so abrasive and academic that is seemed very rude to many of our guests.
The next time the field trip goes to Florida and Georgia, the Okeefenokee Swamp would be an easy and valuable addition.
It would be beneficial to have slightly more downtime in the middle of the trip as opposed to the end.

I would not have spent as long in Georgia. The second half of the trip was interesting, but not as good as the first half. I think we should have stuck with more forest management stuff. St Catherine's island was a unique treat, but the rest of the stuff in Georgia could've been scrapped.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes, the relationship between the student presentations and the field trips was well-designed.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Essential, since it's some of the best field experience that you can get. I would say that it is more important than any FES class.
As a forestry student, these field trips are very important to learning and retaining critical contextual information.
This course provided much needed context for the southeastern forest industry. Seeing production forestry was incredibly beneficial for my understanding of the changing viewpoints in forestry.

I plan on practicing field forestry in the US West. Nevertheless, it is critically important that I understand what managers are doing in other parts of the country. In particular, experiencing fire ecology as we did in Florida and Georgia was very important and relevant to my needs.
Important to see how real forestry is done.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this course because I wanted to learn more about forestry and logging practices and because this trip has had such an excellent reputation over the years.
Wanted field experience and interested in southern forestry.
It was highly recommended by fellow students and alumni.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, this trip solidified a lot of information from Managing Forest Operations.
Absolutely.
Yes, definitely.
Far beyond.
Yes, it was an excellent course

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I would recommend going on this field trip.
Go on it, don't think twice. And go somewhere fun for the second week of break.
GO ON THIS FIELD TRIP!!!!
Absolutely take this field trip! And find a way to meet up with Ann down South!
Be flexible. The nature of this course requires an open mind, of which will yield great treasures of wisdom.
Do it! Study up on the some of the ecological topics before the trip and ask lots of questions - get to know our hosts.
A great way to spend a week of spring break. It's an exhausting week, but you learn a ton!
